Key Arguments: The bill undermines personal freedoms and free speech in Australia.
Government bureaucrats are not in a better position to determine what is 'safe' information than the public.
The definitions of 'Misinformation', 'Disinformation', and 'Serious Harm' in the bill are unworkable.
The bill lacks strong protections for free speech and requires drastic re-drafting.
ACMA should not have unchecked power; there should be statutory mechanisms for review and challenge of ACMA decisions.
The bill should be compatible with Australia's human rights obligations.
The bill should apply to all entities, including government and media organizations.
The bill could lead to complex and costly litigation.
Notable Quotes: This bill is a slap in the face for every Australian.
We cherish personal freedoms and free speech in Australia and we expect to be exposed to ALL information, on ANY platform.

When the public is no longer the arbiter of truth, and that role becomes usurped by bureaucrats and governments, history suggests that the resultant censorship erodes the public's collective trust in authority.

It will not only signal the death knell of the internet as a free marketplace of ideas in Australia, but it will signal to Australian citizens, and to citizens of the globe, that the Australian Government seeks total control of the dissemination of information within its borders.
